claims_to_validate.claim_text: The current Bayzat payroll system lacks automated salary calculation based on precise working days. The platform cannot dynamically adjust salaries proportionally when employees work more or fewer than the standard 26 working days.

The daily wage calculator in payroll settings overrides the leave policy formula for unpaid leave. The system displays a greyed-out formula in leave policy, indicating it will be replaced by the payroll configuration. This causes user confusion about which formula is actually being applied.

System failed to recalculate pending unpaid leave deductions when new salary configurations were created after leave request submission. Deductions were incorrectly based on previous salary configuration instead of current one, resulting in payroll calculation discrepancies.

The End of Service (EOS) gratuity calculator incorrectly handles leap years by using 365 days instead of 366 days for 2024, resulting in an inaccurate total service period and gratuity amount calculation.

End of Service (EOS) calculation is producing incorrect pro-rated amounts due to a rounding or decimal precision error. The daily wage formula (basic + allowances / 30) is configured correctly, but when calculating pro-rated EOS amounts, the system consistently shows amounts that are less than expected by 0.1 or 0.2 decimals.

System gratuity calculation (AED 231,821) slightly differs from manual calculation (AED 252,485), with support explaining the system calculation follows a specific formula based on service duration and daily wage

The system's gratuity calculation may not consistently handle leap year days (February 29th), causing minor discrepancies in total service days and resulting gratuity amount. The specific case showed a difference between 912 and 913 total days, impacting the final calculation.

The system uses a complex calculation methodology for gratuity that differs from manual expectations, specifically in handling partial years above 5 years of service and leap year day counting. The calculation involves segmenting service periods, applying different daily rates (21 days per year for first 5 years, 30 days per year above 5 years), and using specific divisors (366 for leap years, 365 for standard years) for partial year calculations.
System calculates 623 days instead of 622 days when computing job tenure, potentially adding an extra day to gratuity calculations

The daily wage calculator's 'working days' setting causes monthly fluctuations in leave salary accrual calculations. The daily wage rate changes based on the number of working days in each month, leading to inconsistent cumulative totals.

The system calculates leave salary and salary proration using different daily wage formulas. Leave salary uses a 30-day divisor, while salary proration uses a 30.42-day divisor, causing calculation discrepancies.

User initially misunderstood how working days are calculated based on work week configuration. The system was calculating correctly, but the user did not initially understand that their specific work week (NVK Operations) had all 7 days configured as working days.

The system fails to correctly prorate salaries when an employee's departure date is in the future relative to payroll processing. When an employee is offboarded (e.g., on Nov 28th) and payroll is processed earlier (e.g., Nov 27th), the system displays the full monthly salary instead of a prorated amount.

When an unpaid leave request is approved and transaction submitted, then the daily wage calculation is changed and the transaction deleted to recalculate, the system creates duplicate deductions—one with the old calculation and one with the new. Moving the leave request back to pending/accepted does not resolve the issue. Even after deleting the unpaid leave request entirely, the unpaid leave deduction persists in payroll deductions.

When public holidays are added after a leave request is created, the daily wage calculation becomes out of sync between Payroll and Time Off modules. This causes incorrect salary deduction amounts that cannot be retroactively corrected.

The platform currently displays incorrect remarks for daily wage calculations in February, showing 31 days instead of the actual 29 days for leap years. While the backend calculation remains accurate, the frontend display creates potential user confusion.

The system applies a global daily rate configuration that overrides individual policy-specific unpaid leave calculation methods. Instead of using Basic Salary / Working Days as configured, the system uses a global daily rate that calculates deductions using potentially incorrect salary components.

The system shows the daily rate from the payroll processing month (May) instead of the leave occurrence month (April), causing user confusion. The actual deduction amount is calculated correctly, but the displayed daily rate does not match the month when leave occurred.
Salary is based on a standard 26 working days per month, calculated from 365 annual days minus 52 weekly offs, resulting in 313 working days per year divided by 12 months.
